results.title: Rue des Prairies = Meadows Street
results.creator_credit: Denys de la Patelliere and Alexandre Mnouchkine
results.brief_description:
At the end of World War II, Henri, returns from a POW camp to his three children. Life as a widowed father proves very challenging for Henri as the children seem to either get into trouble or turn against their father.

Credits: Producer, Alexandre Mnouchkine ; director, Denys de la Patelliere ; writer, Michel Audiard ; photography, Louis Page ; music, Georges van Parys.
Cast: Marie-Jose Nat, Jean Gabin, France Asselin, Roger Dumas, Claude Brasseur, Leon Zitrone.

results.title: Le Grand Pavois
results.brief_description:
Commandant Favrel is a navy officer married to the job. His naval career is spent training young recruits on ‘La Jeanne d’Arc’ during an eight months around the world ‘trip. Tension errupts in the Favrel household when Favrel’s wife starts begging him to quit the navy and lead a ‘normal’ life. Favrel agrees to a last trip on the ‘Jeanne’ during which he will be commanding Private Hardouin, a young man courting his niece Madeleine.

Credits: Producer, Andre Paulve ; director, Jack Pinoteau ; writers, Jean Raynaud, Jack Pinoteau, Roger Vercel ; photography, Roger Arrignon ; music, Henry Verdun ; assistant director, Claude Pinoteau.
Cast: Jean Chevrier, Nicole Courcel, Marc Cassot, Marie Mansart, Jean-Pierre Mocky, Maurice Sarfaty, Jean Murat.

results.title: Pelle the conqueror = Pelle Erobreren
results.creator_credit: Bille August, Per Holst, Danish Film Institute, Per Holst Filmproduktion and Svensk Filmindustri
results.brief_description: Based on the novel by Martin Andrew Nexos “Pelle the Conqueror” is the epic adventure of two Swedish refugees - eleven year-old Pelle and his elderly, widowed father Lasse (played by Oscar nominee Max Von Sydow). They sail to Denmark in search of a better existence but their dreams quickly fade when they realise that life is not any easier in their new country. Faced with extreme cruelty and poverty, Pelle develops an inner strength that helps him to endure the hardships. Armed with the determination to succeed, he sets out alone to conquer the world. Also stars Pelle Hvengaard, Erik Paaske, Bjorn Granath. Awarded Best Film - Cannes 1988; Best Foreign Film - Oscar 1988 Original subtitled version.

results.title: Rhapsody in blue
results.creator_credit: Irving Rapper, Jesse L Lasky and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: A story that is as enchanting as its central character, the legendary George Gershwin. Robert Alda plays the talented composer in this moving tribute to one of America’s premier musical artists. Following years of practice and an assortment of jobs, Gershwin experienced his first success with “Swanee” (sung in the film by the man who made it famous, the inimitable Al Jolson). Despite his ensuing accomplishments with hit songs and stage success, the musical genius yearned for something greater - to create a unique American music, combining European classics and popular songs. The realisation of Gershwin’s dream is what is perhaps his best known work - the fourteen minute piece entitled “Rhapsody in Blue”. In addition to its inspirational story, this film is musically uplifting, featuring a two-hour feast of classic Gershwin.

results.title: Gueule D'amour = Lady Killer
results.brief_description:
Lucien Bourrache, colonial soldier stationed in Orange, is a lady’s man. While on a business trip to Cannes, Lucien meets Madeleine. Lucien accepts to lend money to Madeleine that she later looses at the gambling table. Although Lucien is smitten by Madeleine, she rejects him. Lucien returns to Orange and resigns from the army in order to follow Madeleine to Paris, where he discovers that she is kept by an other man. Raoul Ploquin was at the time in charge of the French section of the German production company UFA. He had Gremillon under contract to film ‘L’Etrange Monsieur Victor’ which was delayed. Ploquin organised the Gremillon-Gabin meeting and filming started soon after at the Neubabelsberg studios and in Orange and Cannes for the exteriors.

Credits: Producer, Raoul Ploquin ; director, Jean Gremillon ; writer, Charles Spaak ; photography, Gunther Rittau ; music, Lothar Bruhne ; assistant director, Louis Daquin.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Mireille Balin, Rene Lefevre, Marguerite Deval, Pierre Etchepare, Jane Marken, Jean Ayme, Robert Casa, Henri Poupon, Pierre Magnier.

results.title: Marius
results.brief_description:
Marius, who works in his father’s dockside cafe in Marseilles, is set to marry Fanny, his childhood sweetheart. But the call of the sea is too strong for him, and he joins the merchant navy, unware that Fanny is pregnant. The film succeeds best in his portrayal of the little people of Marseilles, their humour and accents. This is the first film of Pagnol’s ‘Marseille trilogy’, followed by ‘Fanny’ (1932) and ‘Cesar’ (1936) [*=Held in our collection].

Credits: Producer, Bob T. Kane ; director, Alexandre Korda ; writer, Marcel Pagnol ; photography, Ted Pahle ; music, Francis Gromon.
Cast: Raimu, Pierre Fresnay, Fernand Charpin, Orane Demazis, Alida Rouffe, Robert Vattier, Marcel Maupi.

results.title: The Pawnbroker
results.creator_credit: Sidney Lumet, Phillip Langner, Roger Lewis and Phoenix Films
results.brief_description: A powerful drama that focuses on Sol Nazerman (Rod Steiger), a middle-aged concentration camp survivor who lost his entire family to the Nazis and now runs a pawnshop in Harlem. His survival is a source of bewilderment and pain which has caused him to take refuge in misery and the condemnation of humanity. He is totally removed from the world of thieves and pimps that frequent his shop and displays no emotional vulnerability to the few people who try to penetrate his icy exterior. When his assistant Ortiz (Jaime Sanchez) sacrifices his own life for Sol during a robbery, the pawnbroker is finally confronted with the inherent goodness of the human spirit. Attacked at the time of its release for being anti-Semitic, anti-Black and pornographic, the film is also memorable for its innovative use of flashbacks to represent the disturbing flashes of Sol’s memory and the soundtrack composed by Quincy Jones. Also stars Geraldine Fitzgerald. Based on the novel by Edward Lewis Wallant.

results.title: The Son of the sheik
results.creator_credit: George Fitzmaurice, J Schneck and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Valentino in his greatest role as the notorious shiek, the defiant and romantic heroic figure of the Arabian desert. This is the classic tale of the English-born but desert-bred Shiek, who fired by the love of a French dancing girl, risks all in his quest to possess her. The torrid sequence of the shiek and his Yasmine, now kidnapped and isolated in his tent, remains a landmark portrayal of sensual desire. A special bonus at the end includes highlights from Valentino’s career and the mass hysteria captured on film when Valentino died.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Fitzmaurice, J Schneck and United Artists Corporation

results.title: Des Enfants Gates = Spoiled Children
results.creator_credit: Michel Piccoli, WDR La Sept Cinema and Bertrand Tavernier
results.brief_description:
A famous director, unable to concentrate on his new script at home with his family, rents a flat in a high rise building. Instead of finding peace and quiet, he gets involved in the tenants’ fight against an exploitative landlord, and with a girl half his age.

Credits: Producers, Alain Sarde, Michel Piccoli, Bertrand Tavernier ; director, Bertrand Tavernier ; writers, Christine Pascal, Charlotte Dubreuil, Bertrand Tavernier ; photography, Alain Levent ; music, Philippe Sarde.
Cast: Michel Piccoli, Christine Pascal, Michel Aumont, Gerard Jugnot, Arlette Bonnard, Genevieve Mnich, Thierry Lhermitte, Michel Blanc, Daniel Toscan du Plantier, Martin Lamotte.

results.title: L'eau a la Bouche = to Each His Own
results.brief_description:
Milena lives with her grandmother in the Chateau d’Aubarede. At the death of the old woman, Milena invites two cousins, Seraphine and Jean-Paul, to attend the reading of the will. Seraphine arrives first accompanied by Robert, her lover, who decides to pass for Jean-Paul. Robert is fascinated with Milena and falls in love with her. As a means of revenge, Seraphine seduces young Miguel, the family lawyer. Then Jean-Paul arrives … The films contains several reference to classic films such as ‘La regle du jeu’ (Renoir, 1939) and ‘Smiles of a summer night’ (Bergman, 1958)

Credits: Producer, Pierre Braunberger ; director, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze ; writer, Jacques Doniol-Valcroze ; photography, Roger Fellous ; music, Serge Gainsbourg.
Cast: Bernadette Lafont, Michel Galabru, Alexandra Stewart, Francoise Brion, Gerard Barray, Paul Guers.
